ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Acquired Auditory Neuropathy Spectrum Disorder (ANSD)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Right ear showed robust DPOAEs and Cochlear Microphonics (normal outer hair cell function) with absent ABR, absent acoustic reflexes, and poor speech recognition.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Profound Sensorineural Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Left ear showed no responses on behavioral or electrophysiological testing, consistent with history of childhood deafness.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: HIV Encephalopathy
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Underlying central nervous system pathology confirmed by CT, likely contributing to the auditory neuropathy.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Functional Hearing Loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Initial behavioral inconsistency suggested non-organic component, but electrophysiology confirmed organic neuropathy; functional overlay possible.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To assess ear canal and tympanic membrane status.
To determine hearing thresholds and configuration.
To evaluate the acoustic reflex arc and retrocochlear function.
To assess outer hair cell function and distinguish sensory from neural loss.
To assess neural synchrony and confirm auditory neuropathy.
To assess cortical detection of sound.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial testing revealed a profound loss in the left ear. Right ear results were inconsistent; initial thresholds were severe-to-profound, but reinstruction yielded a Speech Awareness Threshold (SAT) of 25 dB HL and approximate thresholds of 50 dB HL. Despite this, word recognition was poor/absent. The key finding was the presence of robust DPOAEs in the right ear alongside absent acoustic reflexes and inconsistent behavioral thresholds, raising suspicion for Auditory Neuropathy or functional loss.

tests.name: Otoscopy
tests.result_summary: Normal anatomy and tympanic membranes bilaterally.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Left ear: No response. Right ear: Inconsistent; SAT 25 dB HL, pure-tone thresholds approx 50 dB HL (unreliable), Bone 35 dB HL at 1kHz. Word recognition poor/inconsistent.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Absent ipsilateral and contralateral reflexes bilaterally.

tests.name: Distortion-product otoacoustic emissions (DPOAE)
tests.result_summary: Left ear: Absent. Right ear: Robust emissions present, consistent with normal outer hair cell function.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Electrophysiological testing confirmed Acquired Auditory Neuropathy in the right ear. ABR showed a Cochlear Microphonic (indicating hair cell function) but no synchronous neural waves. ASSR was absent. However, Late-Latency Responses (LLR) were present in the right ear down to mild levels (15-20 dB), indicating sound was reaching the cortex despite brainstem dys-synchrony. Left ear remained unresponsive on all measures.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Cochlear Microphonic present (reverses with polarity); neural waves I-V absent. Left ear: Absent.

tests.name: Auditory Steady-State Response (ASSR)
tests.result_summary: Absent at all frequencies in both ears.

tests.name: Late-latency responses (LLR)
tests.result_summary: Right ear: Responses observed down to 15 dB at 500 Hz and 20 dB at 2000 Hz. Left ear: Absent.

proposed_items: Trial options (hearing aids or FM systems)
counseling_actions: Explain diagnosis of Auditory Neuropathy (inner ear works, nerve connection unsynchronized)
Discuss why speech understanding is poor despite detection of sound
Explain that traditional hearing aids may not clarify speech due to dys-synchrony
Relate condition to recent infections and treatments (HIV/meningitis)

red_flags_present: Discrepancy between objective (OAE) and subjective/neural tests

escalation.rationale_short: Patient diagnosed with terminal HIV encephalopathy and did not pursue audiological treatment.

follow_up_plan.objective: Patient discharged to hospice care and subsequently died.

expected_outcome: Transaxial CT images of the brain showed marked periventricular white matter disease, as well as white matter disease in the pons and the middle cerebral peduncle.
Patient was diagnosed with HIV encephalopathy.
Patient did not pursue audiological treatment options.
Patient was discharged under hospice care and died shortly thereafter.
